subject: Law
title: The Ethics of Surveillance
description: One-minute skill: The Ethics of Surveillance.

hook.text: Your phone tracks your location. Cameras film your walk to work. The government can access much of it. Is that okay?

buildup.text: Surveillance law balances security needs against privacy rights under the Fourth Amendment.

discovery.text: Carpenter v. US (2018) ruled police need a warrant to access cell phone location data. The Court drew a digital line.

twist.text: Facial recognition lets police identify people in crowds. No federal law regulates its use by law enforcement.

climax.text: Some cities have banned police use of facial recognition. Others embrace it. The legal patchwork grows.

punchline.text: Technology sees everything. The law decides how much of that counts as a search.

quiz.question: What did Carpenter v. US require for cell phone location data?
